page.title: 14OLD MOOR FARM
page.content: In 1920 Old Moor was a mixed farm with sheep and cattle but very few crops. The farm grows turnips for feeding sheep and cattle. In 1933 the farm changed to dairy production, land was changed to grass, cabbages, kale and turnips for animal feed. To help the farm, concentrated food was bought in from abroad. In 1939, grain crops were very important because of war shortages. Production was controlled by the government requirements. In 1962 milk production ceased as dairy cattle (short horns) were not popular. Buying and rearing young calves for market followed until 1968. This was followed by pig production which also failed to be viable. This was followed by cereal production and now is producing rape ,winter wheat and barley.
